docs.title: Readability
docs.text: Measure how easy your writing is to read. Get a score. Improve.

docs.title: New Here?
docs.text:
If you've never heard of "readability scores" before, start with these:

  • What is Readability?

    How computers measure writing difficulty. The history, the math, and why it matters.

  • Who Is This For?

    Find your situation: blogger, tech writer, docs team, student, or just curious.

docs.title: The Short Version
docs.text:
Readability formulas count words, sentences, and syllables. They output a grade level: the US school grade that can understand the text. A score of 8 means an eighth grader should follow it.

This tool runs those formulas on your Markdown files and tells you:

Metric What It Tells You Grade Level What school grade can read this Reading Ease How comfortable it is (0-100, higher = easier) Reading Time How long it takes at 200 words/minute

What the Output Looks Like

$ readability docs/

┌─────────────────┬───────┬──────┬───────┬───────┬───────┬──────┐
│ File            │ Lines │ Read │ Grade │ ARI   │ Ease  │ Stat │
├─────────────────┼───────┼──────┼───────┼───────┼───────┼──────┤
│ docs/index.md   │   42  │ <1m  │  7.8  │  8.9  │ 65.2  │ pass │
│ docs/setup.md   │   89  │  2m  │ 11.2  │ 12.4  │ 48.1  │ pass │
│ docs/api.md     │  156  │  4m  │ 14.8  │ 16.1  │ 29.3  │ fail │
└─────────────────┴───────┴──────┴───────┴───────┴───────┴──────┘

docs.title: In CI (GitHub Action)
docs.text:
Check every pull request automatically:

- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    check: true

PRs with overly complex docs fail the check. Writers fix issues before merge.

docs.title: Locally (Command Line)
docs.text:
Check files while you write:

readability docs/getting-started.md

See scores instantly. Revise and re-run until you're happy.

docs.title: What is Readability?
docs.text:
You wrote something. But will people actually understand it?

Readability tools answer that question with numbers. They scan your text and tell you how hard it is to read. This page explains how that works and why you might care.

docs.title: The Simple Version
docs.text:
Readability scores measure two things:

  1. How long are your sentences? Longer sentences are harder to follow.
  2. How complex are your words? Words with more syllables take more effort.

That's it. The computer counts words, sentences, and syllables. Then it does some math. Out comes a score.

A Quick Test

Consider these two sentences:

Hard: "The implementation of the authentication mechanism necessitates the utilization of secure protocols."

Easy: "Login requires secure protocols."

Same meaning. But the second one has shorter words and fewer of them. It scores as easier to read.

docs.title: Where This Came From
docs.text:
Readability formulas aren't new. They've been around since the 1940s.

Year Formula Created For 1948 Flesch Reading Ease US Navy training manuals 1968 Flesch-Kincaid Military documents 1969 Gunning Fog Newspapers and business 1975 ARI Real-time computer analysis

The US military wanted to make sure soldiers could understand their manuals. Newspapers wanted to reach the widest audience. Publishers wanted to match books to student grade levels.

These same formulas now help developers write clearer documentation.

A Strange History

The Flesch Reading Ease formula was created by Rudolf Flesch, an Austrian immigrant who became obsessed with clear writing. His 1955 book "Why Johnny Can't Read" became a bestseller and changed how American schools taught reading.

docs.title: Grade Level
docs.text:
A grade level score tells you what US school grade can read the text. Grade 8 means an eighth grader should understand it.

Score Who Can Read It 6 Sixth graders (age 11-12) 8 Eighth graders (age 13-14) 10 High school sophomores 12 High school seniors 14 College sophomores 16+ Graduate students

Most popular websites aim for grade 7-8. Technical docs usually land around grade 10-14.

docs.title: Reading Ease
docs.text:
Reading Ease flips the scale. Higher numbers mean easier reading.

Score Difficulty 90-100 Very easy (comics, simple fiction) 60-70 Standard (newspapers, magazines) 30-50 Difficult (academic papers, legal docs) 0-30 Very difficult (scientific journals)

docs.title: Technical Writers
docs.text: The people who write software documentation, API guides, and user manuals. They use readability scores to catch overly complex explanations before publishing.

docs.title: Content Teams
docs.text: Marketing teams, documentation teams, and content strategists use readability checks to maintain consistent quality across many writers.

docs.title: Open Source Projects
docs.text: Projects that want their docs accessible to non-native English speakers often set readability standards. Simpler English is easier to translate and understand globally.

docs.title: Students and Bloggers
docs.text: Anyone who writes and wants feedback on clarity. If you're writing a blog post or an essay, readability scores tell you if you're losing readers with complex prose.

docs.title: Newsrooms
docs.text:
Journalists have used these formulas for decades. The Associated Press stylebook recommends keeping sentences under 20 words. Most newspapers target grade 6-8 reading level.

You Don't Need Users

Even if you're just writing for yourself, readability scores help you improve. They're like a spell checker, but for clarity instead of spelling.

docs.title: What This Tool Actually Shows You
docs.text:
When you run this tool on a Markdown file, you get a report. Here's what real output looks like:

$ readability docs/getting-started.md

┌────────────────────────┬───────┬──────┬───────┬───────┬───────┬──────┐
│ File                   │ Lines │ Read │ Grade │ ARI   │ Ease  │ Stat │
├────────────────────────┼───────┼──────┼───────┼───────┼───────┼──────┤
│ docs/getting-started.md│   45  │ <1m  │  8.2  │  9.1  │ 62.3  │ pass │
└────────────────────────┴───────┴──────┴───────┴───────┴───────┴──────┘

Here's what each column means:

Column What It Tells You Lines How long the file is Read How long it takes to read (at 200 words/minute) Grade Flesch-Kincaid grade level ARI Automated Readability Index (another grade metric) Ease Flesch Reading Ease score (higher = easier) Stat Pass or fail based on your thresholds

If a file fails, the tool tells you why:

$ readability --check docs/complex-api.md

docs/complex-api.md:1:1: error: grade level 15.3 exceeds maximum 12 (grade-level)
docs/complex-api.md:1:1: error: reading ease 28.1 below minimum 30 (reading-ease)

GRADE: Files exceed the maximum grade level threshold.
To fix, try:
- Breaking long sentences into shorter ones
- Using simpler words ("use" instead of "utilize")
- Removing unnecessary jargon

docs.title: Why Put This in CI/CD?
docs.text:
CI/CD pipelines run automated checks on your code. Tests, linting, security scans. Why add writing quality?

The same reason you lint code. Linters catch style issues before code review. Readability checks catch confusing docs before they ship.

Without automation: - Complex docs slip through review - Quality varies by author - Nobody notices until users complain

With automation: - Every PR gets checked - Standards stay consistent - Problems are caught early

It's Not Perfect

Readability scores can't tell if your writing is accurate, complete, or well-organized. They only measure sentence and word complexity. You still need human review for everything else.

docs.title: The Limits of Scores
docs.text:
Readability formulas are blunt instruments. They can't detect:

  • Wrong information - A factually incorrect sentence can score as "easy"
  • Missing context - Short sentences without enough explanation score well but confuse readers
  • Good complexity - Sometimes technical terms are necessary and simplifying would be wrong
  • Tone and voice - A robotic easy-to-read doc might be less engaging than a slightly complex one

Use scores as one signal, not the only signal. A high grade level is a prompt to review, not an automatic failure.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
Ready to try it? Here's the quickest path:

# If you have Go installed
go install github.com/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability/cmd/readability@latest

# Run it on any Markdown file
readability README.md

Or see the Getting Started guide for more installation options.

docs.title: Who Is This For?
docs.text: Different people use readability tools for different reasons. Find your situation below.

docs.title: "I Write Blog Posts"
docs.text:
You want feedback on your writing. Are your posts too dense? Will readers bail halfway through?

How to use this:

readability my-post.md

Look at the Grade column. If it's above 10, your post might lose casual readers. Try:

  • Breaking long sentences in half
  • Swapping complex words for simple ones
  • Reading sentences aloud (if you run out of breath, it's too long)

No Installation Needed

Paste your text into any online Flesch-Kincaid calculator to get a quick score. Use this tool when you want to check files regularly.

docs.title: "I Write Technical Documentation"
docs.text:
You maintain docs for software, APIs, or tools. You want to make sure your explanations are clear.

How to use this:

Set up a config file with your standards:

# .readability.yml
thresholds:
  max_grade: 12      # High school senior level
  max_ari: 14
  min_ease: 30

Run checks locally:

readability --check docs/

Or add it to your CI pipeline so every PR gets checked automatically.

Technical Terms Are Okay

Don't dumb down necessary jargon. "API endpoint" is fine in API docs. The goal is clear explanations around the jargon, not removing it.

docs.title: "I Manage a Docs Team"
docs.text:
Multiple writers contribute to your documentation. Quality varies. You want consistent standards.

How to use this:

  1. Set thresholds that match your audience
  2. Add the GitHub Action to your docs repository
  3. PRs that exceed thresholds fail the check

This creates a forcing function. Writers know the standards before they submit. Reviewers don't have to be the "readability police."

# In your GitHub workflow
- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    check: true
    max-grade: 10  # Stricter for user-facing docs

docs.title: "I'm a Student Learning to Write"
docs.text:
You're working on essays, reports, or applications. You want to improve your writing clarity.

How to use this:

Check your draft:

readability essay.md

Compare before and after revisions. Did your edits improve the score? Worse scores after editing might mean you made things more complex, not better.

Revision Practice

Take any paragraph scoring above grade 12. Rewrite it to hit grade 8 without losing meaning. This exercise builds the habit of clear writing.

docs.title: "I Run an Open Source Project"
docs.text:
Contributors come from everywhere. Non-native English speakers read your docs. You want maximum accessibility.

How to use this:

Set stricter thresholds than commercial projects:

thresholds:
  max_grade: 10     # More accessible globally
  min_ease: 40      # Easier to translate
  max_lines: 300    # Shorter, focused pages

Simpler English is easier to: - Translate with automated tools - Understand for non-native speakers - Maintain by rotating contributors

docs.title: "I'm Curious What This Measures"
docs.text:
You don't have a specific use case. You just want to understand readability scores.

Start here:

Read the Introduction for the history and theory. Then run the tool on any text you have lying around:

readability README.md

See what scores your existing writing gets. That context makes the numbers meaningful.

docs.title: "I Need to Convince My Team"
docs.text:
You think your team should care about readability. They're skeptical.

Arguments that work:

  1. Support ticket reduction - Clearer docs mean fewer "how do I...?" questions
  2. Onboarding speed - New users get productive faster with accessible docs
  3. Global reach - Simpler English works better for international audiences
  4. Consistent quality - Automated checks beat inconsistent human review

Arguments that don't work:

  • "The score says it's bad" - Scores are signals, not verdicts
  • "Hemingway wrote at grade 4" - Your API docs aren't literature
  • "It's industry best practice" - Show your own data instead

Don't Weaponize Scores

Readability tools help writers improve. They shouldn't shame or gatekeep. Use them to start conversations, not end them.

docs.title: Not Sure Where to Start?
docs.text:
Try this:

  1. Run readability README.md on any project
  2. Look at the Grade score
  3. Pick one sentence with complex words and simplify it
  4. Run again and see if the score improved

That's it. One file, one sentence, one improvement. Scale up from there.

docs.title: CLI Reference
docs.text: Analyze Markdown files from the command line.

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
go install github.com/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability/cmd/readability@latest

Other Options

See Installation for binaries and building from source.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
# Check a file
readability README.md

# Check a folder
readability docs/

# Fail if issues found (for CI)
readability --check docs/

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Flag Short Purpose --format -f Output format --check Exit 1 on failures --config -c Config file path --verbose -v Show all metrics

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text: Format Best For table Reading in terminal markdown GitHub summaries json Scripts diagnostic IDEs and linters

docs.title: Threshold Flags
docs.text:
Set limits from the command line:

readability --max-grade 12 --max-ari 12 docs/
Flag Controls --max-grade Grade level limit --max-ari ARI score limit --max-lines File length limit --min-admonitions Required callouts

docs.title: More Info
docs.text:
• Commands - All flags
  • Config File - Save settings
  • Diagnostic Output - IDE setup

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: Full reference for the readability command.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
readability [flags] <path>

The path argument is required. It can be a single file or a directory.

Directory Scanning

When given a directory, the tool recursively finds all .md files.

docs.title: --format, -f
docs.text:
Choose how results are displayed.

Value Description table ASCII table (default) markdown Markdown table for GitHub json Machine-readable JSON summary Brief pass/fail summary report Detailed report with distribution diagnostic Linter-style file:line:col format

Example:

readability -f markdown docs/

docs.title: --verbose, -v
docs.text:
Show all available metrics in the output, not just the defaults.

readability -v docs/

docs.title: --check
docs.text:
Enable check mode. The command exits with code 1 if any file exceeds thresholds.

readability --check docs/

CI Usage

Always use --check in CI pipelines. Without it, the command exits 0 even when files fail.

docs.title: Threshold Flags
docs.text: Override thresholds from the config file. Useful for testing different limits.

docs.title: --max-grade
docs.text:
Maximum Flesch-Kincaid grade level allowed.

readability --max-grade 12 docs/

docs.title: --max-ari
docs.text:
Maximum Automated Readability Index score allowed.

readability --max-ari 12 docs/

docs.title: --max-lines
docs.text:
Maximum lines per file. Set to 0 to disable this check.

readability --max-lines 500 docs/

docs.title: --min-admonitions
docs.text:
Minimum callout boxes (notes, warnings, tips) required per file. Set to 0 to disable.

readability --min-admonitions 2 docs/

docs.title: --config, -c
docs.text:
Path to a config file. By default, the tool looks for .readability.yml in the target directory or git root.

readability -c custom-config.yml docs/

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text: Code Meaning 0 All files pass (or check mode disabled) 1 One or more files failed thresholds

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Basic analysis with table output
readability docs/

# JSON output for scripting
readability -f json docs/ > results.json

# CI check with custom thresholds
readability --check --max-grade 10 --max-ari 10 docs/

# Diagnostic output for IDE integration
readability -f diagnostic docs/

# Verbose output showing all metrics
readability -v docs/

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text: Store your thresholds in a .readability.yml file instead of passing flags every time.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Create .readability.yml in your repository root:

thresholds:
  max_grade: 12
  max_ari: 12

That's it. The tool finds it automatically.

Where to Put It

Place the config file in your repository root. The tool searches from the target directory up to the git root.

docs.title: All Options
docs.text:
thresholds:
  max_grade: 12       # Flesch-Kincaid grade level
  max_ari: 12         # Automated Readability Index
  max_fog: 14         # Gunning Fog index
  min_ease: 40        # Flesch Reading Ease (0-100)
  max_lines: 400      # Lines per file
  min_words: 100      # Skip check if fewer words
  min_admonitions: 1  # Required callout boxes
  max_dash_density: 0 # Mid-sentence dash pairs per 100 sentences

docs.title: What Each Threshold Means
docs.text:
Option What It Controls Default max_grade School grade needed to read 16 max_ari Similar to grade, different formula 16 max_fog Complexity from long words 18 min_ease Comfort level (higher = easier) 25 max_lines File length limit 375 min_words Skip short files 100 min_admonitions Notes, tips, warnings needed 1 max_dash_density Mid-sentence dashes per 100 sentences (prevents AI slop) 0

Grade Level Scale

A grade of 12 means "high school senior" level. Most technical docs should target grades 10-14.

docs.title: Different Rules for Different Folders
docs.text:
Use overrides to apply stricter or looser rules to specific paths:

thresholds:
  max_grade: 12

overrides:
  # API docs can be more technical
  - path: docs/api/
    thresholds:
      max_grade: 16
      min_admonitions: 0

  # Tutorials should be simple
  - path: docs/tutorials/
    thresholds:
      max_grade: 8

docs.title: How Path Matching Works
docs.text:
• Paths match from the start (prefix matching)
  • First matching rule wins
  • Put specific paths before general ones
  • Unmatched files use the base thresholds

Example order:

overrides:
  # Specific path first
  - path: docs/api/advanced/
    thresholds:
      max_grade: 18

  # General path second
  - path: docs/api/
    thresholds:
      max_grade: 16

docs.title: Disabling Checks
docs.text:
Set extreme values to skip specific checks:

thresholds:
  max_grade: 100        # No grade limit
  min_ease: -100        # No ease requirement
  max_lines: 0          # No line limit (CLI only)
  min_admonitions: 0    # No admonition requirement
  max_dash_density: -1  # No dash density check

docs.title: Command Line Overrides
docs.text:
Flags override config file values for a single run:

# Use grade 10 instead of config value
readability --max-grade 10 docs/

# Use a different config file
readability --config strict.yml docs/

docs.title: With GitHub Actions
docs.text:
The action finds .readability.yml automatically:

- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    check: true

See GitHub Action Configuration for action-specific options.

docs.title: Diagnostic Output
docs.text: The diagnostic format produces linter-style output that IDEs and CI tools understand.

docs.title: The Format
docs.text:
file:line:column: severity: message (rule-id)

Each issue gets one line. This format works with VS Code, Vim, and most CI systems.

Sample Output

docs/api.md:1:1: error: Grade 18.5 exceeds threshold 16.0 (readability/grade-level)
docs/api.md:1:1: warning: Found 0 admonitions, minimum is 1 (content/admonitions)

docs.title: How to Use It
docs.text:
readability --format diagnostic docs/

For CI pipelines, add --check to fail on errors:

readability --check --format diagnostic docs/

docs.title: Rule IDs
docs.text:
Each issue has a rule ID you can reference:

Rule ID Level What It Checks readability/grade-level error Flesch-Kincaid grade readability/ari error ARI score readability/gunning-fog error Gunning Fog index readability/flesch-ease error Reading ease score structure/max-lines error File length content/admonitions warning Callout boxes

docs.title: Severity Levels
docs.text:
• error - Fails the check, blocks CI
  • warning - Should fix, but won't block CI
  • info - Informational only (future use)

docs.title: VS Code
docs.text:
Create .vscode/tasks.json:

{
  "version": "2.0.0",
  "tasks": [
    {
      "label": "Check Readability",
      "type": "shell",
      "command": "readability --format diagnostic docs/",
      "problemMatcher": {
        "owner": "readability",
        "fileLocation": ["relative", "${workspaceFolder}"],
        "pattern": {
          "regexp": "^(.+):(\\d+):(\\d+): (error|warning): (.+) \\((.+)\\)$",
          "file": 1,
          "line": 2,
          "column": 3,
          "severity": 4,
          "message": 5,
          "code": 6
        }
      }
    }
  ]
}

Run with Terminal > Run Task > Check Readability. Issues appear in the Problems panel.

docs.title: Vim / Neovim
docs.text:
Add to your config:

set errorformat+=%f:%l:%c:\ %t%*[^:]:\ %m

Then run :make with the readability command.

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
- name: Check docs
  uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    format: diagnostic
    check: true

docs.title: Generic CI
docs.text:
readability --check --format diagnostic docs/

The command exits with code 1 when errors are found. This fails the CI job.

docs.title: Pre-commit Hooks
docs.text:
The pre-commit hook uses diagnostic format by default:

repos:
  - repo: https://github.com/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability
    rev: v0.11.0
    hooks:
      - id: readability-docs

docs.text: Get Readability running in under five minutes. Choose the method that fits your workflow.

docs.title: Choose Your Path
docs.text:
Method Best For Setup Time GitHub Action Automated CI/CD checks 2 minutes Pre-commit Hook Local checks before commits 3 minutes CLI Tool Manual analysis, scripting 2 minutes

New to Readability?

Start with the GitHub Action. It requires no local installation and catches issues automatically on every pull request.

docs.text:
Here's what you'll get: a clear report showing which files need attention.

docs/api-reference.md:1:1: error: Grade 14.5 exceeds threshold 12.0
docs/getting-started.md:1:1: pass
docs/index.md:1:1: pass

3 files analyzed: 2 passed, 1 failed

docs.title: Docker
docs.text:
Run the readability CLI using Docker. The image is available from GitHub Container Registry.

Multi-Architecture Support

The image works on both Intel/AMD (linux/amd64) and ARM (linux/arm64) systems. Docker picks the right one for you.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Pull the image and analyze your docs:

docker pull ghcr.io/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability:latest

docker run --rm -v "$(pwd):/workspace" \
  ghcr.io/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability:latest /workspace/docs

docs.title: Image Tags
docs.text:
Pick a tag based on how you want to track updates:

Tag Description latest Most recent stable release vX.Y.Z Exact version (e.g., v1.10.0) vX.Y Latest patch for a minor version vX Latest release for a major version

docs.title: Check with Thresholds
docs.text:
Fail if grade level is too high:

docker run --rm -v "$(pwd):/workspace" \
  ghcr.io/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability:latest \
  --check --max-grade 12 /workspace/docs

docs.title: JSON Output
docs.text:
Get results as JSON for scripts or CI:

docker run --rm -v "$(pwd):/workspace" \
  ghcr.io/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability:latest \
  --format json /workspace/docs

docs.title: Use a Config File
docs.text:
Mount your config and reference it:

docker run --rm -v "$(pwd):/workspace" \
  ghcr.io/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability:latest \
  --config /workspace/.readability.yml /workspace/docs

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
Signed Images

All images are signed with Cosign. You can verify them before use.

docs.title: Verify Image Signature
docs.text:
Check that the image came from our CI:

cosign verify ghcr.io/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability:latest \
  --certificate-identity-regexp 'https://github.com/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability/.*' \
  --certificate-oidc-issuer https://token.actions.githubusercontent.com

docs.title: Verify SBOM
docs.text:
Each image has a signed bill of materials (SBOM):

cosign verify-attestation ghcr.io/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability:latest \
  --type cyclonedx \
  --certificate-identity-regexp 'https://github.com/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability/.*' \
  --certificate-oidc-issuer https://token.actions.githubusercontent.com

docs.title: Base Image
docs.text:
The container uses Google's distroless base image. This means:

  • No shell or package manager
  • Runs as non-root user
  • Only the readability binary is included

docs.title: GitLab CI
docs.text:
readability:
  image: ghcr.io/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability:latest
  script:
    - readability --check --max-grade 12 docs/

docs.title: CircleCI
docs.text:
jobs:
  readability:
    docker:
      - image: ghcr.io/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability:latest
    steps:
      - checkout
      - run: readability --check --max-grade 12 docs/

docs.title: Jenkins
docs.text:
pipeline {
    agent {
        docker {
            image 'ghcr.io/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability:latest'
        }
    }
    stages {
        stage('Check Readability') {
            steps {
                sh 'readability --check --max-grade 12 docs/'
            }
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Pick the installation method that matches how you want to use Readability.

docs.title: GitHub Action
docs.text:
No installation needed. Add this step to any workflow file in .github/workflows/:

- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    check: true

Version Pinning

Use @v1 for the latest stable release. This automatically updates to new minor versions while staying on major version 1.

docs.title: Pre-commit Hook
docs.text: Pre-commit hooks run checks before each commit. This catches issues early, on your local machine.

docs.title: Step 1: Add the Hook
docs.text:
Create or update .pre-commit-config.yaml in your repository root:

repos:
  - repo: https://github.com/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability
    rev: v0.11.0  # Check releases for latest version
    hooks:
      - id: readability-docs

docs.title: Step 2: Install and Test
docs.text:
pre-commit install
pre-commit run readability-docs --all-files

docs.title: Available Hooks
docs.text:
Hook ID What It Checks readability All markdown files in the commit readability-docs Only files in the docs/ folder

Configuration

Create a .readability.yml file to customize thresholds. See Configuration File for options.

docs.title: CLI Tool
docs.text: The command-line tool lets you run checks manually or in scripts.

docs.title: Option 1: Go Install
docs.text:
If you have Go 1.21 or later:

go install github.com/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability/cmd/readability@latest

Verify it works:

readability --version

docs.title: Option 2: Download Binary
docs.text:
Download a pre-built binary from the releases page.

Available platforms:

  • Linux (amd64, arm64)
  • macOS (amd64, arm64)
  • Windows (amd64)

docs.title: Option 3: Build from Source
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability.git
cd readability
go build -o readability ./cmd/readability

docs.title: Next Step
docs.text: Continue to Quick Start to run your first analysis.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Run your first readability analysis and understand the results.

docs.title: Your First Analysis
docs.text:
Point the tool at your documentation folder:

readability docs/

You'll see a table like this:

┌─────────────────────────┬───────┬─────────┬─────────┐
│ File                    │ Grade │ Flesch  │ Status  │
├─────────────────────────┼───────┼─────────┼─────────┤
│ docs/index.md           │ 8.2   │ 62.5    │ pass    │
│ docs/getting-started.md │ 10.1  │ 55.3    │ pass    │
│ docs/api-reference.md   │ 14.5  │ 38.2    │ fail    │
└─────────────────────────┴───────┴─────────┴─────────┘

Understanding the Scores

  • Grade: School grade level needed (lower is simpler)
  • Flesch: Reading ease score (higher is easier)
  • Status: Pass/fail based on your thresholds

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text:
Choose the format that fits your needs:

Format Command Best For Table readability docs/ Human reading Markdown readability -f markdown docs/ GitHub summaries JSON readability -f json docs/ Scripts and automation Diagnostic readability -f diagnostic docs/ IDE integration

docs.title: Check Mode
docs.text:
Add --check to fail when thresholds are exceeded. This is useful for CI pipelines.

readability --check docs/

The command exits with code 1 if any file fails. Use this in your CI to block PRs with readability issues.

docs.title: Custom Thresholds
docs.text:
Override defaults from the command line:

readability --check --max-grade 12 --max-ari 12 docs/

Or create a .readability.yml file for persistent settings:

thresholds:
  max_grade: 12
  max_ari: 12
  max_lines: 400
  min_admonitions: 1

Config File Location

Place .readability.yml in your repository root. The tool finds it automatically.

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text:
• CLI Reference - All command options
  • Understanding Metrics - What each score means
  • GitHub Action - Automate your checks

docs.title: GitHub Action
docs.text: Check documentation readability on every pull request. No local setup needed.

docs.title: Quick Setup
docs.text:
Add this to .github/workflows/docs.yml:

name: Check Docs

on:
  pull_request:
    paths:
      - 'docs/**'

jobs:
  readability:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
        with:
          path: docs/
          check: true

What This Does

Every PR that changes files in docs/ will run a readability check. If any file fails, the PR shows a red X.

docs.title: What You Get
docs.text:
The action adds a summary to your workflow run:

File Grade ARI Status docs/index.md 8.2 9.1 pass docs/api.md 15.3 17.2 fail

Click any run to see the full report.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Works out of the box
  • Shows results in GitHub's job summary
  • Reads your .readability.yml config
  • Fails the build when docs are too complex

docs.title: Learn More
docs.text:
• Configuration - All inputs and outputs
  • Examples - Common patterns

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: All inputs and outputs for the GitHub Action.

docs.title: Inputs
docs.text:
Input What It Does Default path Folder or file to check docs/ format Output format markdown config Config file path Auto-detect check Fail on violations false max-grade Grade limit From config max-ari ARI limit From config max-lines Line limit From config summary Show job summary true summary-title Summary heading Documentation Readability Report

Config File

The action finds .readability.yml in your repo root automatically. You don't need to set the config input unless using a different file.

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text:
Use outputs in later steps by adding id to the action:

- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  id: readability
  with:
    path: docs/

- run: echo "Passed: ${{ steps.readability.outputs.passed }}"
Output What It Contains report Full results as JSON passed true or false files-analyzed Number of files checked

docs.title: Full Example
docs.text:
- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    format: markdown
    check: true
    max-grade: 12
    max-ari: 14
    max-lines: 500
    summary: true
    summary-title: Docs Check

docs.title: Job Summary
docs.text:
The action writes a report to your workflow's summary page. This shows:

Column Meaning File Which file Lines File length Read Reading time Grade Grade level score ARI ARI score Ease Reading ease score Status Pass or fail

docs.title: Turn Off Summary
docs.text:
- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    summary: false

docs.title: Custom Title
docs.text:
- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    summary-title: "Docs Quality"

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Common patterns for using the GitHub Action.

docs.title: Report Only
docs.text:
Show results without failing the build:

- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/

When to Use This

Good for getting started. See the reports, then add check: true once you've fixed issues.

docs.title: Block Bad Docs
docs.text:
Fail the PR if docs are too complex:

- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    check: true

docs.title: Custom Limits
docs.text:
Set your own grade level:

- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    check: true
    max-grade: 10
    max-ari: 10

docs.title: Process Results in Script
docs.text:
Get JSON output and use it:

- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  id: readability
  with:
    path: docs/
    format: json

- name: Show failed files
  run: |
    echo '${{ steps.readability.outputs.report }}' \
      | jq '.[] | select(.status == "fail")'

docs.title: Check Multiple Folders
docs.text:
Run separate checks with different rules:

# User guides: strict
- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/guides/
    check: true
    max-grade: 8

# API docs: relaxed
- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/api/
    check: true
    max-grade: 14

docs.title: With Config File
docs.text:
Use a .readability.yml for settings:

- uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
  with:
    path: docs/
    check: true

The action finds the config file automatically.

docs.title: Only on Doc Changes
docs.text:
Run only when docs change:

name: Check Docs

on:
  pull_request:
    paths:
      - 'docs/**'
      - '.readability.yml'

jobs:
  readability:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: adaptive-enforcement-lab/readability@v1
        with:
          path: docs/
          check: true

docs.title: Understanding Metrics
docs.text: This tool measures how easy your writing is to read. Here's what each score means.

docs.title: The Key Numbers
docs.text:
Metric What It Tells You Grade Level School grade needed to understand Reading Ease Comfort level (0-100, higher = easier) ARI Another grade measure, based on characters Fog Index Years of schooling needed

Quick Rule

For most docs, aim for grade 10-14 and ease above 30.

docs.title: What's a Good Score?
docs.text: Your Audience Target Grade Target Ease Everyone 6-8 60-70 High schoolers 9-12 50-60 Tech workers 12-14 30-50 Experts only 14+ Under 30

docs.title: How to Improve
docs.text:
Bad scores usually mean:

  • Sentences are too long
  • Words have too many syllables
  • Writing is passive instead of active

Fix it by:

  1. Break long sentences into shorter ones
  2. Use simple words (say "use" not "utilize")
  3. Write "the API returns data" not "data is returned"

docs.title: Learn More
docs.text:
• Grade Level Scores - The main metrics
  • Flesch Reading Ease - The comfort score
  • Thresholds - Picking limits
  • Admonitions - Callout boxes
  • Dash Density - Preventing AI slop patterns

docs.title: Admonitions
docs.text: Admonitions are callout boxes. They highlight tips, warnings, and notes in your docs.

docs.title: What They Look Like
docs.text:
In MkDocs, you write them like this:

!!! tip "Pro Tip"
    Use short sentences. They're easier to read.

!!! warning
    This breaks in version 2.0.

Why Check for These?

Admonitions break up walls of text. They make docs easier to scan. This tool checks that you use at least one per file.

docs.title: Common Types
docs.text: Type When to Use note Extra info that's good to know tip Best practices and shortcuts warning Things that might cause problems danger Critical issues to avoid example Code samples and use cases info Background context

docs.title: Setting the Minimum
docs.text:
By default, each file needs at least one admonition.

In your config:

thresholds:
  min_admonitions: 1  # Default

From the command line:

# Turn off the check
readability --min-admonitions 0 docs/

# Require at least 3
readability --min-admonitions 3 docs/

docs.title: Different Rules for Different Folders
docs.text:
Some content needs more callouts than others:

thresholds:
  min_admonitions: 1

overrides:
  # Changelogs don't need callouts
  - path: docs/changelog.md
    thresholds:
      min_admonitions: 0

  # Tutorials need more
  - path: docs/tutorials/
    thresholds:
      min_admonitions: 3

docs.title: Do's and Don'ts
docs.text:
Do:

  • Add !!! tip for shortcuts readers might miss
  • Add !!! warning for common mistakes
  • Add !!! example to show real usage

Don't:

  • Add empty admonitions just to pass the check
  • Put basic info in callouts (use regular text)
  • Overuse them (too many loses impact)

Quality Over Quantity

The check counts admonitions. It can't judge if they're helpful. Don't game the metric with empty boxes.

docs.title: Syntax Guide
docs.text:
All of these work:

!!! note
    Basic callout.

!!! warning "Watch Out"
    With a custom title.

!!! tip inline
    Flows with text.

The tool detects any word after !!! as a valid type.

docs.title: Dash Density
docs.text: Dash density measures mid-sentence dash patterns that often indicate AI-generated content.

docs.title: What It Detects
docs.text:
The tool counts three patterns:

  1. Space-hyphen-space (-) - Example: "The system - which processes data - runs fast"
  2. Em-dash with spaces (—) - Example: "Documentation — especially technical — needs clarity"
  3. Em-dash without spaces (—) - Example: "This feature—unlike others—offers benefits"

Why This Matters

AI-generated content frequently overuses mid-sentence dashes as a stylistic crutch. Human writers use them occasionally, but AI tends to insert them formulaically when adding parenthetical information.

docs.title: How It's Calculated
docs.text:
Dash density is the number of mid-sentence dash occurrences per 100 sentences.

Example:

The system - which processes data - runs efficiently.
Documentation — especially technical docs — requires clarity.
This feature—unlike others—offers benefits.

This has 6 dashes in 3 sentences = 200 dashes per 100 sentences.

docs.title: Default Threshold
docs.text:
By default, no mid-sentence dashes are allowed (max_dash_density: 0).

This strict default helps prevent AI slop patterns from entering your documentation.

In your config:

thresholds:
  max_dash_density: 0  # Default - no dashes allowed

From the command line:

# Allow some dashes (5 per 100 sentences)
readability --max-dash-density 5 docs/

# Disable the check entirely
readability --max-dash-density -1 docs/

docs.title: How to Fix Violations
docs.text: When you see a dash density error, rewrite the sentence using these techniques:

docs.title: Use Commas
docs.text:
Before: 

The system - which processes data quickly - runs efficiently.

After: 

The system, which processes data quickly, runs efficiently.

docs.title: Split Into Separate Sentences
docs.text:
Before: 

Documentation — especially technical documentation — requires clarity.

After: 

Documentation requires clarity. Technical documentation especially needs clear writing.

docs.title: Restructure to Avoid Parenthetical Constructions
docs.text:
Before: 

This feature — unlike traditional approaches — offers significant benefits.

After: 

Unlike traditional approaches, this feature offers significant benefits.

Or:

This feature offers significant benefits compared to traditional approaches.

docs.title: Different Rules for Different Folders
docs.text:
You might want to allow dashes in some content:

thresholds:
  max_dash_density: 0  # Strict by default

overrides:
  # Academic content might need some dashes
  - path: docs/research/
    thresholds:
      max_dash_density: 10

  # Disable check for legacy docs
  - path: docs/legacy/
    thresholds:
      max_dash_density: -1

docs.title: Do's and Don'ts
docs.text:
Do:

  • Use commas for parenthetical information
  • Split complex sentences into simpler ones
  • Restructure to eliminate unnecessary asides

Don't:

  • Use mid-sentence dashes as a replacement for proper sentence structure
  • Insert parenthetical clauses that break reading flow
  • Rely on dashes to connect loosely related ideas

docs.title: What Gets Excluded
docs.text:
The dash density check only examines prose content. The following are automatically excluded:

Excluded Content

  • Code blocks: All fenced code blocks (```yaml) and inline code
  • Tables: All table content including headers and cells
  • Lists: Unordered (- Item) and ordered list markers and content
  • Admonitions: MkDocs-style callouts (!!! note) and their content

Example:

# This dash is DETECTED ❌
The system - which processes data - runs fast.

# These dashes are IGNORED ✓
- List item with - dash in content
| Column - 1 | Column - 2 |
!!! note "Title - with dash"
    Content with - dashes here

Only the first line counts toward dash density. Everything else is excluded from prose analysis.

docs.title: AI Slop Indicators
docs.text:
High dash density correlates with:

  • Formulaic sentence structure
  • Excessive parenthetical information
  • Reduced reading flow
  • Potential AI-generated content

By keeping dash density at or near zero, you ensure your documentation maintains human-quality writing patterns.

docs.title: Flesch Reading Ease
docs.text: This score tells you how comfortable your text is to read. Higher numbers mean easier reading.

docs.title: The Scale
docs.text:
Score How It Reads Who Can Follow 90-100 Very easy 5th graders 80-90 Easy 6th graders 70-80 Fairly easy 7th graders 60-70 Normal 8th-9th graders 50-60 Fairly hard 10th-12th graders 30-50 Hard College students 0-30 Very hard Grad students

For Tech Docs

Most technical docs land between 30-50. That's fine for expert readers. Aim higher (50-60+) for tutorials or user guides.

docs.title: What Affects the Score
docs.text:
The formula looks at:

  • Sentence length - Longer sentences lower the score
  • Word complexity - More syllables per word lower the score

docs.title: Targets by Content Type
docs.text: Content Target Score API reference 30-50 User guides 50-60 Tutorials 60-70 Marketing 70+

docs.title: How to Improve
docs.text:
1. Shorten sentences - Break long ones apart
  2. Use simple words - "use" beats "utilize"
  3. Go active - "The API sends data" not "Data is sent"
  4. Cut filler - Remove words that don't add meaning

Before and After

Before (score ~40): "The implementation of the authentication mechanism necessitates the utilization of secure token-based verification protocols."

After (score ~70): "Login uses secure tokens to verify users."

docs.title: Grade Level Scores
docs.text: These scores estimate what school grade can read your text. A score of 8 means an 8th grader should understand it.

docs.title: The Four Metrics
docs.text:
Metric What It Measures Best For Flesch-Kincaid Words per sentence, syllables General docs ARI Characters per word Tech content Gunning Fog Long words (3+ syllables) Business writing Coleman-Liau Character counts Academic papers

Which One?

Start with Flesch-Kincaid. It works well for most content. Add ARI if you write technical docs with code terms.

docs.title: Flesch-Kincaid Grade Level
docs.text:
The most common metric. It looks at sentence length and syllable count.

What affects it:

  • Longer sentences raise the score
  • Words with more syllables raise the score

Target: Grade 8-12 for most docs.

docs.title: ARI (Automated Readability Index)
docs.text:
Uses character count instead of syllables. This makes it better for technical content. Code terms often have many characters but few syllables.

What affects it:

  • More characters per word raise the score
  • Longer sentences raise the score

Target: Grade 10-14 for technical docs.

Why ARI for Tech Docs?

Words like "config" and "param" are short in syllables but long in characters. ARI catches this better than other metrics.

docs.title: Gunning Fog Index
docs.text:
Counts "complex words": those with three or more syllables. Common endings like "-ing" and "-ed" don't count.

What affects it:

  • More complex words raise the score
  • Longer sentences raise the score

Target: Grade 12-14 for business content.

docs.title: Picking the Right Metric
docs.text:
Your Content Primary Metric Secondary User guides Flesch-Kincaid - API docs ARI Flesch-Kincaid Business docs Gunning Fog Flesch-Kincaid Tutorials Flesch-Kincaid ARI

Multiple Metrics

You can check more than one. Use max_grade for Flesch-Kincaid and max_ari for ARI in your config.

docs.title: Thresholds
docs.text: Thresholds are your limits. Set them too strict and everything fails. Too loose and bad docs slip through.

docs.title: Starting Points
docs.text: Pick based on who reads your docs.

docs.title: For Technical Docs
docs.text:
thresholds:
  max_grade: 12
  max_ari: 14
  min_ease: 30
  max_lines: 500

This Is the Default

These values work for most developer docs. Start here and adjust as needed.

docs.title: For User Guides
docs.text:
thresholds:
  max_grade: 10
  max_ari: 12
  min_ease: 50
  max_lines: 300

Stricter limits because non-technical readers need simpler text.

docs.title: For API Reference
docs.text:
thresholds:
  max_grade: 14
  max_ari: 16
  min_ease: 20
  max_lines: 1000

Looser limits because expert readers can handle dense content.

docs.title: Different Rules Per Folder
docs.text:
Not all docs are alike. Use overrides:

thresholds:
  max_grade: 10

overrides:
  # API docs can be harder
  - path: docs/api/
    thresholds:
      max_grade: 14

  # Tutorials must be easy
  - path: docs/tutorials/
    thresholds:
      max_grade: 8

Path Matching

Paths are relative to your repo root. End folder paths with / to match all files inside.

docs.title: Skip Short Files
docs.text:
Very short docs give bad scores. The formulas need enough text to work well.

thresholds:
  min_words: 100

Files under 100 words won't fail checks.

docs.title: Limit File Length
docs.text:
Long files are hard to navigate. Set a line limit:

thresholds:
  max_lines: 500

Split Long Docs

If a file hits this limit, break it into smaller focused pages. One topic per page works best.

docs.title: All Available Thresholds
docs.text: Setting What It Limits Default max_grade Flesch-Kincaid grade level 12 max_ari Automated Readability Index 14 min_ease Flesch Reading Ease (higher = easier) 30 max_fog Gunning Fog Index 16 max_lines Total lines in file 500 min_words Minimum words to check 50 min_admonitions Required callout boxes 1
